Author: buzzer9229
Content: Alright I'm going to use this to share to you my thoughts regarding politicians in Indonesia and bits of information.

Author: buzzer9229
Content:
@everyone today's sermon will be about **Wiranto**, currently one of the presidential advisers to Jokowi.

Us youngins see him as just another name in Indonesian politics, but a lot of oldies know that this is the only man Prabowo Subianto fears. Wiranto was probably the villain of the Reformation era (contrasting Amien Rais as the hero). He started off his career as a military officer in the 1960s far away from the capital, in Manado. He managed to climb his way into the prestigious Kostrad (Komando Cadangan Strategis Angkatan Darat) who were the most well equiped and well trained and became a brigade commander. 

Wiranto gained his bars in Kostrad because it was politically close with the government and his time in Kostrad led to him being chosen as an aide-de-champ to none other than **Soeharto**. His time with Soeharto won him brownie points and then he was selected as the Commander of Kostrad. It was during this time that Wiranto was involved in military factionalism and joined the nationalist camp of the military alongside former president SBY, former PSSI chairman Agum Gumelar and Soekarno loyalist Hendropriyono.

When 1997 strike Indonesia with financial crisis, Wiranto began distancing himself from Soeharto. As Panglima TNI, Wiranto took actions that was independent of Soeharto's orders and was suspected by Soeharto to harbour treasonous sentiments. He balanced Soeharto's worries, with his own political ambitions and with the security of the state.

In 1998, Wiranto refused to listen to Soeharto's orders anymore as the Indonesian economy worsens, and the riots intensifies, holding Soeharto's safety hostage. In a combination of Amien Rais' provocation, the activists involvement, Harmoko's betrayal, Soeharto finally gave in to the pressure and stepped down.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: It was in 1998 did Wiranto ordered Prabowo Subianto to what led to warcrimes, from detaining of activists, kidnapping and even murder.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: Some people speculate during this time that Wiranto realized how much power he had over Indonesia and planned to take over Indonesia and install himself as President

Author: buzzer9229
Content: But everyone agreed that Wiranto stood between Prabowo's ambitions during the time to become the youngest president in Indonesia.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: In Habibie's presidency, Wiranto was more hawkish. Wiranto let Habibie and Golkar knew that the military did not owe any loyalty to them and thus kept on leveraging more power from Habibie. At one time, Wiranto threatened Habibie that he will depose Habibie in a military coup should he removed Indonesian interest from Timor. Wiranto backed down from his threats when Habibie countered by saying he will get the UN involved and make sure Wiranto removed from his post.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: During the withdrawal of Indonesian troops from Timor, Wiranto was accused of human rights violations and war crimes that happened under his command.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: Habibie later knew that Wiranto was a threat to the fledging Indonesian democracy, so he promoted Habibie to Minister of Defense under his presidency to guarantee the loyalty of the military. The move worked but it angered many Soehartoist within the government. An angry Prabowo (who demanded to be put in charge over the military) attempted a coup de tat by marching into the presidential palace with a division of his Kostrad troops but was stopped by Wiranto.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: Not only that, Prabowo's anger was rooted from Wiranto's appointment of him as Kostrad commander.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: In Gusdur's presidency, Wiranto made sure he was a part of the cabinet and became Menkopolhukam. Three months into his ministerial position, Gusdur fired Wiranto from the post because Wiranto continued to leverage his military control over the government. This was seen as an obstacle by Gusdur who wanted to exert civillian control over the military.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: Wiranto also allegedly dumped most of his war crimes allegation on his subordinate Prabowo, a rumor that still persist today.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: He realized that in a more democratic era, he cannot continue to leverage his increasingly loose grip over the military. This was when Wiranto joined Golkar. Wiranto expressed his desire to become president and participated in the legendary 2004 Golkar National Convention that practically shaped the modern political landscape. He was up against **Jusuf Kalla** (a businessman from Makassar), **Akbar Tandjung** (former Minister State Secretary), **Surya Paloh** (THE Indonesian entrepreneur), **Prabowo** (his former subordinate and technically Crown Prince), **Cak Nur** (a friend to Gus Dur and Muslim intellectual) and **Hamengkubowono X** (King of Yogyakarta).

Author: buzzer9229
Content: Wiranto won the convention, but lost the presidency to his former colleague SBY. He later lost the Golkar elections to become leader of the party to Jusuf Kalla, who had the backing of the president. Wiranto cited that he was disappointed by SBY's lack of support to him owing to their army days.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: Unable to seek political advancement, Wiranto and his faction broke off from Golkar and joined the Megawati and Wahid opposition against SBY's government. He formed a politically party called **Hanura**, one of the breakaways of Golkar alongside Gerindra, PKP and Nasdem. Hanura was more conservative than Golkar, in contrast to the nationalist Gerindra, centrist PKP and liberal Nasdem.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: After SBY stepped down, Wiranto, following both PDIP and PKB, supported Joko Widodo's bid. He later became Jokowi's Coordinating Minister for Political, Legal and Security Affairs.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: However, Wiranto's politicking inside the cabinet costed him his party as he mismanaged it to the ground. Wiranto later left the party to avoid further conflicts with its members and joined PAN.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: Right now, Wiranto is one of the primary backers of the Jokowi faction. He is the head of the Presidential Advisory Committee, a member of PAN, and one of the masterminds behind the TKN. Though Wiranto is no longer as powerful as he was, Wiranto still commands the respect of many military officers as he is the second oldest living former Commander of the Indonesian Armed Forces (the oldest living Commander of the Indonesian Armed Forces is Try Sutrisno, who is 88 as of now).

Author: ruffruffgrrh
Content:
Been wanting to share bout my reading lately, feel free not to engage, I just need to yap üôè

As an econ undergrad I've been reading some papers about our country ‚Äî specifically about our country's welfare as measured by the Human Development Index and bits and bobs about human capital.

When evaluating the welfare of a nation, indicators like IPM, HDI, HCI observe three aspects of said nation: their economic wellbeing (income per capita), their health (survivability rate/life expectancy), and education (years of schooling or literacy rate)

Indonesia's most critical aspect is education above anything else

Healthcare has been getting better here. Although inequality remains prominent, on average, the figures are pretty good. Increasing life expectancy, low mortality rate for newborns. Our health infrastructure seems to be getting better as well, above 50% of households in Indo have access to basic healthcare and sanitation. The trend for income is also increasing, I guess to an extent.

Education though, is something else I think. The participation rate decreases for every education level: at the top, only about 6% of Indonesians go to college in 2022 (data from BPS).

It's also not a big news that our PISA score is far behind the others, but not only that, it's actually been decreasing for the past few years

The effects I would like to think are quite big too for the working force

I once read this report from LPEM FEB UI. From there I got to know that the one sector which absorbs the most labour in Indo, agriculture, contributes to the lowest share of our national income. The labor share has been decreasing in that sector whilst its share remains stagnant, implying efficiency and also movement in the labor force. But even though there's been a noticeable movement in labor, turns out those people could only shift to other low-wage sectors üòì

Makes me think that our country is in dire needddd of more accessible education

Author: snuckel4
Content: There was a convo about BIN

Author: snuckel4
Content:
```What is it like to work at the State Intelligence Agency (BIN)?
This question is about 'working at BIN' and not 'working for BIN'.

People who work for BIN are divided into two 'castes'.

First, the 'officer' caste (those who work at BIN), which includes:

Individuals recruited, selected, and trained by BIN through official education programs.

Intelligence officers from the Indonesian National Armed Forces (TNI) or National Police (Polri) who are assigned to BIN.

Civil servants with special expertise. They may come from the Directorate General of Taxation, Customs, the Financial Transaction Reports and Analysis Center (PPATK), the Attorney General's Office, etc.

Second, the 'non-commissioned officer' and 'enlisted' caste. These are:

Individuals with influence and information networks, such as leaders of mass organizations, motorcycle gangs, or thugs.

Recruits and assets managed by intelligence officers. Field intelligence agents like Pollycarpus and Gun Jack certainly have an 'officer' as their superior.```

```In addition to these two groups, BIN also has administrative staff, like any other government agency. However, this is not particularly interesting to discuss.

Next, I would like to clarify some misconceptions about BIN personnel.

First, graduates of BIN's official education program (now STIN) belong to the officer caste, and they do not disguise themselves as street food vendors (or similar professions). Intelligence officers act as supervisors for field agents. If they do go into the field, their targets are high-profile figures. For example, if I wanted to spy on Donald Trump, would it make sense for me to disguise myself as a hot dog vendor in front of the White House? It would be much better to pose as a diplomat or journalist with access to the White House, right?```

Author: snuckel4
Content:
```Second, there is often suspicion that BIN monitors the internet. This is not entirely incorrect. The internet is monitored by both BIN and the National Cyber Agency (formerly Lemsaneg). However, there is a difference in how BIN and the Cyber Agency operate. The Cyber Agency can crawl the internet and extract the data they want, while BIN does this manually. If both agencies were monitoring Quora, the Cyber Agency would look for any posts from anyone that they find 'interesting'. On the other hand, BIN would only monitor 'dangerous' posts made by users with significant influence (e.g., those with many followers) or users suspected of being involved in certain networks (e.g., terrorism). So, if a user with few followers writes something 'dangerous', BIN would most likely ignore it.

There was once a rumor that BIN had a big data base monitoring the internet. This is clearly a hoax, not because Indonesia couldn't do it, but because even if such a thing existed, it would be the job of the Cyber Agency, not BIN (although collaboration between BIN and the Cyber Agency is not impossible).

Finally, if you're interested in becoming an intelligence officer, apply to STIN. Being an intelligence officer carries risks similar to being a soldier. If you reach the officer level, you typically won't be doing dangerous work (though there are always exceptions, hehe). As long as the intelligence officer doesn't do anything foolish (e.g., giving orders to kill via a personal cell phone, as in the Munir case), they will remain invisible and undetected.```

Author: hovischoch
Content:
I don't necessarily agree with this take, above all these Ministries are Independent from the Military and it's a different field as well.

SAR Nasional does not equal to Military, their goals are all different; including their methods.

Defense and Military is like two different roads that lead to the same location, mostly those within the Defense Ministry makes decisions and also does analysis/research on what move they're gonna make for their country's sake.

Military in the other hand is waiting for a call to be made, they're trained physically and learn much more in regards to On-Land Strategy.

Author: hovischoch
Content:
If you want my solution, here's my analysis:

In regards to this topic, we often forget that we have a Government Structure that has been formed and agreed upon, one above the other; can't argue nor go against that.

This discussion about the Military being able to be assigned/tasked within the Government happened during a Meeting by Komisi I of DPR, a discussion in which the goal was to revise the Constitution (specifically UU TNI)

If **I were to be in this situation**, there are many lengths to go through such as attempting to form an Independent Body; where their tasks are to oversee, review, and evaluate such Military Activity within the Government. This unforutnately doesn't remove the Military from Government business, however this still instills authority for the Civillians against the Military (basically telling the Military that we are all different and that you have no authority in this business lol)

If that couldn't be done, then **atleast do a weekly/monthly evaluation or review of what the military has been doing within the government.** This encourages transparency and we can also do a forum where most debates/decision making happens, whatever idk

Author: huhu_matcha
Content:
Prabowo is basically following India‚Äôs policies. The massive difference is that India is self-sufficient (in terms of food production). They invest in their agriculture, they‚Äôre now investing in manufacturing and the recent tax policies means that the middle class is taxed less and have disposable income to spend.
The Indian diaspora invests a lot into the economy. 

Not saying India is perfect. But, the economic advancements they‚Äôve achieved in the past 20 years is commendable. Especially considering Indonesia in the early 90s was doing WAY better than India. Look at where we are at now.

Author: snuckel4
Content: Here's a lesson for everyone:

Author: snuckel4
Content:
Hiking and Climbing are not a joke, it is not an activity you can master just by once or multiple times. You will be lost, you will starve and you will die.
The first thing need to do when you're entering survival mode is to think of STOP, that is:
**Sit**, Stop and don't move too far away recognisable surrounding, calm yourself
**Think**, think of the next thing to do according to what is happening
**Observe**, watch surrounding, everything, every detail.
**Plan**, make a plan how to solve the situation and make it quick.

Nature is cruel and it will not show any mercy to you, you're a guest and you must be humble. When things go south-prioritise your safety first then the others.

Author: snuckel4
Content: I am willing to educate anyone who want to ask what to do in such situation, and I do not mind to teach anyone who want to learn if they're still a novice in hiking.

Author: snuckel4
Content:
Flint and Steel/Feros Rod are a unique type of firemaker that actually can still spark a fire even when its wet. 
Your ligther however, if its the common type of lighter you must dismantle its component, the gas pipe, the flint, they must be dry first.

When wood or branches are wet, you need your knife-scrape them like cheese, most wood that are wet because of rain the inside of the wood is dry. Collect as much of it and make sure it is small enough to be able to catch your flint spark or fire.

Author: nerosalt
Content: @constant can you quickly give me a crash course on how socialist/communist ideology can solve europe's economic stagnation?

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content: Communists aim to abolish the state money and class it is the very antithesis to what an "economy" is and anyone that tells you otherwise is a glorified, radical social democrat

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content: Those that use the examples of USSRs achievements in a short period of time is also arguing in favour of Capitalism's strength

Author: oneandonlycharles
Content: Would you say the USSR were state capitalists because the favor output based on strong arming everyone to industrialize?

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
The USSR was capitalist because they had generalized commodity production, wage labour, the law of value, classes, etc.
Safe to say they didnt achieve socialism or lower phase communism as Marx/Engels defined

Maybe Socialism if defined by the common general term - State owned
Still doesn't make it socialist/communist (Marx never differed the two terms btw) because what defines a mode of production isnt ideology, or morals, or if it makes good numbers on a paper or not

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content: Well the USSR was historically progressive for industrializing and bringing about Capitalism and thus dissolving feudalism, so Lenin was right in that sense (and also the New Economic Policy which introduced more capitlaist elements)

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
His understanding of dialectics is rigid and dogmatic

> "According to dialectics, an increase in quantity (amount of graad, temperature), can change the nature, nature creates a new quality. After the quantity increases from 80celc to 100celc, the nature changes: Water becomes vapor, quantity becomes quality. change in number (quantity) becomes a change in nature (quality). from water to vapor. 
> Dialectics concludes the movement of ‚Äúyes‚Äù and ‚Äúno‚Äù with a ‚ÄúNegation der negation‚Äù. The ‚Äúyes‚Äù is initially canceled. This negation is also canceled. Let's take a grain of rice and plant it. After a while the rice seed is no longer a seed, but has become a tree. This is one negation: The tree produces more seeds than it started with. Here there is a nullification of the tree: The seed canceled the tree. In the whole process, the rice play, we have the rice seed, the tree (invalidation) and many rice seeds (nullification). This is what is named: Negation der negation"
(Forgot which page but its in the dialectics section iirc, dialektika materialis dan dialektika idealis kayaknya)

Quantitative change overturning into qualitative change is true, but all of these dogmatic natural examples are indeed products of Engels' shitty philosophy in DoN and Anti-Duhring
It's always wrong to use these examples because they're cyclical, the negation of the negation is the negation of negation as such. A good example is Marx explaining the negation of the negation of private property, where private property goes through its determinate negation / positive negation when it's extended to a universal level and the negation of the negation follows when society has forgotten about property entirely.

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
Imagine a straight line with no points, such line is infinite. Now draw point A and point B on the line and you've negated its infinity.
Point A is the negation of its infinity from one side, point B is the negation of its infinity from the other
It's derived from the word negative
Because it negates

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
Christianity can be seen as a negation of negation, it's helpful to have an overview of theology when dealing with Hegel.
God creates man in his own image (perfect) -> man negates himself with sin, gains consciousness and otherness from God, but can recognize God has made him in his image -> God sends his Son among the living to absolve us of our sins (absolute negation of the negation)
And here you can see how sublation isn't circular, since it has produced new knowledge

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
you cant be a marxist if you are religious, dialectical materialism is rigidly atheist 

> "Social-Democracy bases its whole world-outlook on scientific socialism, i. e., Marxism. The philosophical basis of Marxism, as Marx and Engels repeatedly declared, is dialectical materialism, which has fully taken over the historical traditions of eighteenth-century materialism in France and of Feuerbach (first half of the nineteenth century) in Germany‚Äîa materialism which is absolutely atheistic and positively hostile to all religion. Let us recall that the whole of Engels‚Äôs Anti-D√ºhring, which Marx read in manuscript, is an indictment of the materialist and atheist D√ºhring for not being a consistent materialist and for leaving loopholes for religion and religious philosophy. Let us recall that in his essay on Ludwig Feuerbach, Engels reproaches Feuerbach for combating religion not in order to destroy it, but in order to renovate it, to invent a new, ‚Äúexalted‚Äù religion, and so forth. Religion is the opium of the people‚Äîthis dictum by Marx is the corner-stone of the whole Marxist outlook on religion. Marxism has always regarded all modern religions and churches, and each and every religious organisation, as instruments of bourgeois reaction that serve to defend exploitation and to befuddle the working class. "

[From *The Attitude of the Workers‚Äô Party to Religion* (Lenin)](https://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1909/may/13.htm)

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
And to answer your question on a communist society, you would have first understand the material conditions which give rise to religion in the first place

Religious thought arose out of the same historical developments as any other philosophy

> Religion is, indeed, the self-consciousness and self-esteem of man who has either not yet won through to himself, or has already lost himself again. But man is no abstract being squatting outside the world. Man is the world of man ‚Äì state, society. This state and this society produce religion, which is an inverted consciousness of the world, because they are an inverted world. Religion is the general theory of this world, its encyclopaedic compendium, its logic in popular form, its spiritual point d‚Äôhonneur, its enthusiasm, its moral sanction, its solemn complement, and its universal basis of consolation and justification. It is the fantastic realization of the human essence since the human essence has not acquired any true reality. 
https://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1843/critique-hpr/intro.htm

Religion is an attempt to understand the world, to understand one's self-conscience; while simultaneously not accepting one's real autonomy. Humans exist within society, and religion is an invention of society, religion serves to comfort people, serves to provide knowledge, morality, answers to questions of our purpose and task in society, with the promise of an afterlife as an award for this dedication.

Author: dovaluffy
Content: Meritocracy exists but is significantly compromised by systemic inequalities. While hard work and talent matter, privilege provides critical advantages: financial safety nets allow full academic focus without survival concerns, while social connections open doors regardless of ability. Truly merit-based opportunities typically require exceptional talent from underprivileged individuals, demanding they be "the top 1% of the top 1%" to access what average students with privilege obtain easily. Meanwhile, universities have transformed from affordable knowledge centers to expensive economic necessities, with tuition costs doubling in just a few years, further entrenching these advantages. Merit can enable success, but within a system heavily weighted toward those with pre-existing advantages.‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

Author: psyoppress
Content: condemnatory use of the term in 1958 by Michael Dunlop Young in his work The Rise of the Meritocracy, who was satirizing the ostensibly merit-based Tripartite System of education practiced in the United Kingdom at the time; he claimed that, in the Tripartite System, "merit is equated with intelligence-plus-effort, its possessors are identified at an early age and selected for appropriate intensive education, and there is an obsession with quantification, test-scoring, and qualifications"

Content: Honestly really depends on the execution of said idea, as the others above me said what matters is the safety net itself and the quality of education the majority of people receives (in a short amount of time like SMA/SMK, LPK, and whatever qualifications or certifications r available to the common folk) i still believe that intelligence is part hereditary and an "adaption" on how to survive in one's enviroment, on average (from what ive seen personally) the less fortunate has a more practical way of doing things (like karet gas, makeshift lamps, makeshift tools and etc) compared to more fortunate people (mostly comes from experience), but more fortunste people has access to a different skillset thats more valued even though the ability to solve problems is (mostly) the same, so it really depends on your culture and your adaptibility really, i also know some rich folks that are somewhat knowledgeable but otherwise lazy and uneducated even though they come from prestigious universities

Author: huhu_matcha
Content: Even better is implementing a TAFE system in Indo. So people who don‚Äôt have access to do S1/S2 can do certificate courses (short-term) that equips them with skills to find a job.

Author: huhu_matcha
Content:
Then supplement that with changing the perception of tertiary education providers to move towards micro-courses.
Example: RMIT Online has a 6 week course in Product Management, which they created to rival General Assembly‚Äôs offering. Since RMIT is a more recognised name, it‚Äôs more appealing.

Author: fellowmen
Content: its more affordable, and people can have earn specific skill faster

Author: huhu_matcha
Content:
This is why I see Indo as land of opportunities. There‚Äôs so many problems to solve and it‚Äôs exciting.
The issue is that the current system  makes it hard to implement change.

Content: I‚Äôd love for Indo to attract and involve their diaspora even more. Right now, the incentives are so low

Content:
Exactly and the way the government can make it better is by partnering with Industry.

So, there needs to be an assessment of the skills that our industries need and can‚Äôt fulfill in the market. Then, the TAFE courses prioritises those skills in demand and subsidies those courses too.

The better the collab between Industry & Education, the better we‚Äôll be in building our people

Author: the_second_morgan
Content:
Don't know if this will fit in with the rest, but this is what I've learned so far in my life. Please take it with a grain of salt.

Well, where do I start? Humans made mistakes. They always do. In many fields, mistakes are never left in the hands of mankind. From my personal observation on the matter, I grew up in a place where people often do not learn from their mistakes. In school, even now, whenever I see my friends making a mistake and the teacher points it out, they only say "yes" or "sorry, I would not do it again," like they wouldn't, but in fact they still did. And let me say, back then, I was a part of that demographic. I lash out whenever my mistakes are being displayed right in front of me, or argue about that mistake more and say that I didn't do it or I didn't have the intention to do it, while I did and then start blaming them, an example of my ad hominem.

.

Author: the_second_morgan
Content:
One thing that made me open my eyes to the greater picture is regret, and regrets last forever; sometimes, it might fall off, and sometimes, it rises again. When I faced my first regret, I thought that this was my fall.

*"But the heart has its own memory, and I have forgotten nothing."*

- Albert Camus, The Fall.

Depression hits me like a wildfire; it entrenched you deep, and you are overwhelmed with the sense of hopelessness, the thought that the world will see and will hate you for it for what you have done. But in the middle of this torturous epoch, I saw an answer that I had to search myself, not by books, not by philosophies, not by anything external. But myself. I was stupid back then; you can expect how stupid I am simply from the fact that I hated studying and always got addicted to video games in my childhood, but through that answer, I finally became open, free, kind, and a bit understanding. Since then, the word 'sorry' has been embedded into my mind, and I will always say it whenever I make a mistake. No matter if they forgive me or not, it is better to say it than to say nothing.

*"It is better to do something than to do nothing while waiting to do everything."*

- Winston Churchill

.

Author: the_second_morgan
Content:
From that, I develop it into kindness, and from that kindness, I spread it to my friends and family. My voluntary work as a teacher starts from spreading kindness, and at the start of the career, that's where I became an intellectual. The pain within me had to be sealed for me to work at my highest function, and my advice will remain the same.

*"Don't be like me, but follow what I do that you consider good."*

Truly, one way to find yourself a peaceful solitude is to learn how to accept yourself, learn how to forgive yourself, and learn how to make an effort to make yourself better before you decide to make others better. Don't focus on influencing the materials of the world that is out of your control. Depression can be resolved by learning how to accept, and if you ever need assistance, please reach out. The world may be going against you, but those who know you, those that understand you better than anybody, will come to help you at your lowest. Reminding you that not all is coming against you. To become your own Ubermensch, is to wage war with your own body and claim the first and best victory, that is to **conquer yourself.**

Author: the_second_morgan
Content: ```That will be all, I thank you for those who reads this in their spare time.```

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: I would go with redistribution of wealth according to 5th Sila: Social Justice.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: 5th Sila not only emphasize people simply getting equal justice but also equal rights. This suggested the idea of progressivism in distribution of resources and wealth for the mass populace, including land reforms, state-led industries and welfare programs.

Content:
Pancasila definitely wasnt make with wealth protection in mind, 
theres nothing that directly implies anything like wealth protection and wealth distribution besides social justice and people tend to argue that social justice would be equal opportunity and not equal income

But like i do not think Muhammad Yamin, Soepomo, and Soekarno would have privatization of assets in mind especially post colonialism (hell soekarno subscribed to socialism)

So redistribution of wealth just makes more sense imo 
Please CMIIW

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: The economic vision of Pancasila is based on "gotong royong" a philosophy that emphasize the idea of working together to make a better economy (mutual cooperation)

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: where wealth is managed collectively rather than concentrated in the hands of a few. It supports cooperatives, state-owned enterprises, and policies that redistribute economic benefits to society.

Author: stayflyyyy
Content: There's no good reason to keep obeying feudal tradition unless feudalism still exists

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Furthermore, as much as Pancasila support private ownership, it discourages any form of economic exploitation. This includes economic monopoly along with large ownerships that exceeded the government itself

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Thus it only support capitalism, but not towards an extreme one

Content: Alas it is not pure capitalism, but rather leaning towards resources distribution

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: To start off, the Pancasila itself was being pretty vague in its statements. Thus it caused many different interpretations that are not resolved to begin with. It is in practice, has economic inequality that still persists, despite the principle of social justice part. Pancasila offers broad ethical guidelines, but it does not provide a specific economic framework that is detailed enough to tackle modern economic challenges.

Author: someforgottentoramers7670
Content:
I think it is a given that the 5 Principles somehow comforms the best ideas/talking point of the Left regarding people.

I'm not sure what Soepomo and Yamin's ideology had in mind when they---along with Soekarno---formalized Pancasila. But for sure, They had to embrace aspirations/voices from various people of different backgrounds. Thus absorbed some "interesting" ideas about people, which mainly came from the Left.

 Had the founding fathers refused to change some lines in the 1st principle in response to some people of Eastern Indonesia, what would be the becoming of Indonesia as a unity in diversity ?

Author: .tigervi
Content:
If that's what "communism" is, why do they need to take natural resources from third countries?Why do they need the practice of imperialism?

Communism is:
1. Abolition of the state.
2. The elimination of social classes so that no one oppresses or is oppressed.
3. The elimination of money, commodity production, private property (not personal property) and so on.
4. Communist Society.
5. The Abolition of Capitalism.


If it were only to handle my needs, capitalist countries could also do it with their welfare state programs like the Nordic countries.

If you still persist like this, this is social democracy.Social democracy does not aim to overthrow capitalism but using capitalism to realize their demanded social programs.

Author: .tigervi
Content:
Socialism and DOTP are an inseparable unit. Socialism is a transition to communism. Since the bourgeoisie was overthrown, the bourgeoisie has been fighting tooth and nail against socialism and the proletariat. therefore dotp is needed by the proletariat not only for the construction of socialism towards communism but also as a weapon to fight back against the bourgeoisie who are trying to destroy socialist construction. dotp and socialism do not overlap and actually need each other.

Dotp and socialism js the lower stafe of socialism. Communism is the highest stage. In Low stage communism/socialism, there are bourgeois laws that can be abolished and there are also remnants of bourgeois laws that will be eroded over time in a socialist state.That is why the transition from Socialism to Communism is so long.It should also be remembered that even though capitalism has become global, the conditions of capitalist development in each country are different.

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
Read Lenin
> Socialism means the abolition of classes. The dictatorship of the proletariat has done all it could to abolish classes. But classes cannot be abolished at one stroke.
> And classes still remain and will remain in the era of the dictatorship of the proletariat. The dictatorship will become unnecessary when classes disappear. Without the dictatorship of the proletariat they will not disappear.
> Classes have remained, but in the era of the dictatorship of the proletariat every class has undergone a change, and the relations between the classes have also changed. The class struggle does not disappear under the dictatorship of the proletariat; it merely assumes different forms.
https://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1919/oct/30.htm
The era of socialism and the era of the dictatorship of the proletariat are clearly distinct

Author: redex_guy
Content:
in the first phase of communist society (usually called socialism) "bourgeois law" is not abolished in its entirety, but only in part, only in proportion to the economic revolution so far attained, i.e., only in respect of the means of production. "Bourgeois law" recognizes them as the private property of individuals. Socialism converts them into common property. To that extent--and to that extent alone--"bourgeois law" disappears.

However, it persists as far as its other part is concerned; it persists in the capacity of regulator (determining factor) in the distribution of products and the allotment of labor among the members of society. The socialist principle, "He who does not work shall not eat", is already realized; the other socialist principle, "An equal amount of products for an equal amount of labor", is also already realized. But this is not yet communism, and it does not yet abolish "bourgeois law", which gives unequal individuals, in return for unequal (really unequal) amounts of labor, equal amounts of products.

This is a ‚Äúdefect‚Äù, says Marx, but it is unavoidable in the first phase of communism; for if we are not to indulge in utopianism, we must not think that having overthrown capitalism people will at once learn to work for society without any rules of law. Besides, the abolition of capitalism does not immediately create the economic prerequisites for such a change.

Now, there are no other rules than those of "bourgeois law". To this extent, therefore, there still remains the need for a state, which, while safeguarding the common ownership of the means of production, would safeguard equality in labor and in the distribution of products.

Author: redex_guy
Content:
The state withers away insofar as there are no longer any capitalists, any classes, and, consequently, no class can be suppressed.

But the state has not yet completely withered away, since the still remains the safeguarding of "bourgeois law", which sanctifies actual inequality. For the state to wither away completely, complete communism is necessary. 

-V.I. Lenin-
State and Revolution (Chapter V)

Author: .tigervi
Content:
Socialism in one country does not mean abandoning internationalism. Socialism in one country, in essence, socialism can be built in one country or several countries as a fortress of the proletariat to fight capitalism. The influence will be international and will inspire proletariat in other countries to carry out revolutions. 


My claim is only that capitalism has gone global, but the development of capitalism in each country is different.There are generalities and there are specificities due to the material conditions prevailing in that country.But we must not ignore external factors.

Author: kaviarormonroe
Content:
????
What is the correlation between this and my original point which is Socialism and DoTP being different eras?
I didnt even say that after revolution it immideately goes to communism, im just saying that Socialism and DoTP is DIFFERENT !
If you disagree with me, you disagree with Marx in Critique of the Gotha Programme saying that lower phase communism is "communism not as it has developed, but as it arises from capitalist society" and then saying that "the revolutionary era of transformation, the dictatorship of the proletariat" or something to that accord

Also something funny is that Lenin is talking about a different thing here. This is a mistranslation (Apparent by the very weird terminology)
Lenin's terminology is very weird here, I'd even say incorrect, because Marx makes it clear that the proletariat can't take hold of the bourgeois machinery and Lenin also acknowledges this in State and Revolution too. Maybe it's a fault of mistranslation in one way or another, because Marx never uses "bourgeois law" either but "bourgeois right", and in Russian the word for right/law is the same. I don't think it's correct to imply that a class state (or state as a state) exists under LPS,  Marx describes bourgeois right just as the principle which governs commodity exchange, and in Conspectus in Bakunin he mentions that the state disappears with class rule (Engels also reiterates this by saying that once the state serves society as a whole, and no longer struggles against a class, the state as a state is abolished, and it starts withering away), and obviously the bourgeoisie no longer exist in Lower Phase Communism, because there is no longer the class relation which exclusively owns the means of production and enslaves the propertyless mass with wage labour, there are only producers (which Lenin also says in the same passage where he calls the state "bourgeois").
So really, we are talking about different things entirely !!

Author: huhu_matcha
Content:
In terms of food, Indonesia is falling behind Thailand - from what I can see in Australia.
2 years ago, Thai restaurants started popping up in bigger numbers. And I‚Äôm not talking about your usual cheap Thai takeout. These were restaurants that were featured and mentioned in good food guides.

Indonesia? We have so much potential but we‚Äôre lagging. There‚Äôs this hesitance to innovate and also we really pander to Western tastes way too much.

When I spoke to a few Indo restaurant owners here in Melb, they‚Äôre‚Ä¶ old school. To add to it, the rising cost of wages in Aus makes it really hard to sustain a restaurant business.

There‚Äôs opportunities for sure. We‚Äôre not capitalising it - or maybe we‚Äôve lost the wave that Korean restaurants rode 5 years ago.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
To start off, IP by its definition was not understood by many. An average Indonesian will know what is an Indonesian product and content creator, but they won't know what is an IP for many of its cases. Thus, we need an incentive to make people understand what is IP, starting with creative communities and some simplified videos, explaining about what is IP. I've seen some videos talking about IP and its definition but they lacked views while being in podcast format. For faster application and strengthening, I suggest for the upgrade of DGIP first along with help and recruitment centers being built for local influencers being able to apply for it. 

Another idea is to create: 

"Rumah IP Nasional (IP Bersama, IP Merah Putih, etc, you can come up with a good name)," an institution that is centralized or public-private center for IP Education, legal aid for creators, and even cultural preservation for traditional cultures, while it can be built in Yogyakarta, Bandung and Denpasar as creative cities.

Author: mahakardus
Content:
You cannot expect every diverse communities in this country to think alike. And no other massive country in this world is separated by water like indo.

But i'll give you my idea. More decentralization and autonomy. Acknowledge the basic fundamental rights of provinces and communities to be able to solve their own issues, including the economy.

Aceh, depsite its issues, is the model of what truly regional autonomy suppose to be. With its own particular institutions and even their own local party.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
There are multiple answers:
1. During contact with the Aborigines and Colonists, the Aborigines reached 1 million in populace at max. Something that isn't in Indonesia with larger populace.
2. Indonesia is divided by multiple sultanates and kingdoms, with each of them are actually as advanced as equivalent to 16th century feudal states. We even managed to have semi-modernization efforts before being assimilated into the colonial regions in some areas.
3. Smallpox killed many Aborigines, while in Indonesia  we already got exposed to smallpox and some diseases in 16th century, making us much more resistant.
4. We have way more resistance movements than the Aborigines as they got assimilated from tribes to the society. One example is the Acehnese rebellion that reached to a point that a Dutch need to learn from the Acehnese to understand its weakness by culture and traditions.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: 5. During the colonization, Aborigines were reported to have small birth rate with its family structures were shattered. Indonesian family structures and birth rate still went normal even skyrocketed in Java.

Author: yisan
Content: native americans is a whole can of worms no one wants to untangle for many reasons.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
But I will break it down one by one for you for the Native American in US and Canada in a simplified form so everybody can understand:
1. In Canada, the natives were having forced assimilation though a less militarized version like in the US. As a matter of fact, the Native American were treated much better under the Canadian though not spotless in their marginalization history against the natives. There are more visible political engagement with Indigenous leaders in Canada than in the US. Just like any Native American, they were also dying in population due to their lower populace yet wiped out by smallpox and other diseases. Furthermore similarly like Australia, they are still divided by tribes, but less technologically inferior and have some edges. They even learn and become auxilaries for the colonial forces, especially during French Indian War and American War of Independence.
2. US is a whole pack to unpack. The most devastated ones were obviously the western native Americans due to the first arrival of the colonies. And with some similar reasons, like the smallpox, they got wiped out more in those sectors rather than wars. Some fought due to warlike culture, some fought when their lands are getting stolen or occupied by settlers, and others did for defenses. Meanwhile the Midwest and Eastern Native Americans though managed to avoid the similar fate like the the western Native Americans, also faced some migrations from these native tribes, in which some migrating tribes even fought each other or against other already settled tribes in there. The Southern Native Americans in US suffered some similar fate like the Western Native Americans, but with some of the most famous battles and resistance (my favorite one: Seminole). Midwest also got consolidated later on, with eastern and southeastern natives became the last consolidated ones as they basically become what you've seen in Wild West movies about the Indians. They adopted horses and even use them a lot.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: The natives managed to adopt horses and turned them into their own warhorses while acquiring the usage of firearms from their trade to fight against the Americans, and in a few cases with the Mexicans in southern states. But after they got defeated and consolidated (with some treaties did happened), most of them are relocated to Oklahoma

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Oklahoma is still and right now being a place for many native Americans or at least their remnants to stay in there

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: And yes, their populace are lower with many mingled with Americans thus their blood isn't exactly pure anymore. Some of those who stayed to become natives though had their own legal independence, faced exploitation and certain conflicts in interest with the government in their land rights

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: As the US, like to seized more lands from them, even until now

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Now let's talk about Latin America for Native Americans, which in this case, I will shortened it to Mexico only since Carribean Island and South America can have their own very long story

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: 3. Mexico: There are a lot to cover in there, but what most people didn't know is that the natives in there were still relied on by the Spanish during colonial era. As a matter of fact, due to the lack of colonial populace in Mexico, many native rulers are still installed during its early colonization after Aztec Empire got destroyed, but as a bunch of puppets. Spanish also encouraged intermarriages as many native american elites married Spanish aristocracy to continued producing heirs. These people are what we known today as Mestizo (native and Spaniard blood). During 19th century, the Aztecs were painted in a much lighter picture since the Mexican independence (as a form of cultural agenda to rival the superior European culture). Even then, the fact that these natives are still done dirty by the Mexicans in certain cases such as poverty and inequality. Caste War of Yucat√°n broke out which proved to be one of the most successful native revolt in early modern era, though later on defeated. Thus the natives in Mexico is more resistant against the colonial forces with Mexican independence that were done by mix natives and other ethnic groups proved how the natives somewhat more successful than the other natives, but ironically, the Latinos didn't really see the natives (or more pure blooded ones) as their own brothers as tensions are still there during that period.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Oh and just like other natives, they were dying from smallpox, possibly even more than other natives.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Maoris are at first peaceful with the Europeans. As a matter of fact, during their early colonization, the Maoris called these Europeans as PƒÅkehƒÅ, which they acquired weaponries and ideas from them. The Maoris even adopted writing pretty quickly from these Europeans through a cultural exchange of ideas and technology. Just like the other natives, they suffered mortality rate from diseases like influenza, smallpox and measles. Until the 1860's, conflicts between Maoris and colonial government is generally limited and ended with peace deals due to lower population of British colonists. Only in 1860's does the situation further broke out into an all out war between New Zealand colonial government against various Maoris tribes (Search New Zealand Wars). The Maoris after they were defeated, did get forced to assimilate with the British until 20th century when their population started to recover. They actually managed to get a middle ground on Maoris adopting western medicines while still retaining their cultural practices (thus their population stopped declining at a significant rate).

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: And yes, the Maoris are heavily outnumbered too during British colonization in 1860's though before that, they were outnumbering the British as in 1839, only 2,000 settlers were reported to be a part of the colonial crown.

Author: nick3512
Content: I'm currently living in Canada and am interested to hear your explanation about why Native Americans were treated much better than Canadians especially right after you said that the natives had forced assimilation (which is correct through residential schools, the Indian Act, etc)

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
Ahhh my mistake saying that. I was meant to say that the Natives were treated much better under the Canadian, but I didn't realized that. The natives did get better treatment but still horrible nevertheless in their own parts of history. I will say tho, in early colonial Canada, First Nations were treated as nations better than your average colonial settlers. This is mainly due to three things: 
1. Low colonial population 
2. Resource routes
3. Treaty Protection

Early eras of colonization is understandable since the populace in Canada are not dominating in terms of its colonial settlers compared to the 13 colonies. Thus there are compromises being made as the British and its colonial government had to recognized the importance of the natives as political actors. Sometimes they even used these natives for their own wars including French Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War and even in 1812 War. Though later on these usage of natives would be limited, they played early importance due to the fact that the British were lacking in manpower. And to anger a bunch of tribes that had given you their voluntary manpower would not be the wisest move in politics. The resource one is obvious considering the natives had been working with Hudson Bay Company in fur trade. Some natives even hold some rivers and important routes for the fur trade, in which the British had to treat these people with a friendly approach or at least diplomatically mutual if they did not want to lose their access for fur trade. Compare that to some colonial settlers in remote areas who were struggling to survive, indebted to trading posts, and had no influence in decision-making. Lastly for the treaty, the Royal Proclamation of 1763 recognized the natives land rights to not be settled by the British. Though in all fairness, later on these treaties will be broken multiple times in the future by the Brits themselves.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Thus it is enough to say that they were treated fairly good enough during the early colonial history, but it is only later on when the geopolitical had changed with arrival of technologies that the government had started to pushed for assimilation programs. And this is where the native rights were broke multiple ever since in late 18th century, reaching its climax by 19th and 20th century under the government encouragement itself.

Author: nick3512
Content: Thx for the explanation. Can you explain what do u mean by: "First Nations were treated as nations better than your average colonial settlers"?

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: I meant that colonial governments (especially the British) often recognized Indigenous groups as collective political entities or nations, that had to be dealt with formally during the early age of colonization, whereas ordinary settlers were just individuals or subjects with very little power like your average farmers or hunters in colonial settlements.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Though keep in mind this is not an argument used to justify the British colonial rule on the natives, nor the Canadian government

Author: nick3512
Content:
I'm obviously not an expert in Canadian history therefore, while I'm going to give my take on this issue, I'm open to hear if I'm wrong. Overall, I agree with your explanation if not for the detail such as:

While some early interactions were based on mutual respect and cooperation, I am questioning how long did it last?  Per your explanation, native rights were broke in late 18th century, but there was history of a bounty for indigenous scalps as early as the 1700s for example. My understanding, the respect and cooperation didn't last for long.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Ah yes, what I meant by native rights were things such as lands since I did mentioned the treaty beforehand. And you are right to say that the respect and cooperation didn't last for long, ever since the recognition for the natives was nothing but a strategic necessity to begin with (and I mentioned before the British needed to do this to secure trade routes while attaining some auxilaries). Europeans were few in number and needed Indigenous alliances, knowledge, trade access, and military support from 1600's to early 1700's. It is only when colonial population grew in size and power when that respect had been lost and broken on larger picture. Then about the Indigenous scalping, it was mostly happen in the 13 colonies than in Canada to begin with. Though in all respect, there are a few events of scalping happening in Canada, but less like in the other colonies. One notable example is the Mi'kmaq militias who fought against the British in Father Le Loutre‚Äôs War where the British did issued a scalping bounty on the Mi'kmaq who had been known to be a long time ally for the French. Yet even then, the natives fought more against the British in 13 colonies than in Canada, exceptions can be given when they are at war against the French. Thus there aren't a lot of conflicts between the natives and the Canadian settlers (generally speaking), alas the relation between the natives and Canadians are somewhat better than what the other British settlements in 13 colonies experienced, even after becoming independent.

Author: nick3512
Content: Thx for the explanation!

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: You're welcome, I am also open to your own perspective since I believe you are also a Canadian yourself (or you are just living in Canada currently but not as a born Canadian)? That will be quite interesting to see what the Canadians thought about the native rights and treatments

Author: nick3512
Content:
I'm Indonesian who happen to be living in Canada at the moment. Can't say much from the historical perspective, but, I can say that the Canadian gov is doing the right thing especially if we compare to what happen in the US (I used to live in the US). 

Today, any public event (concert, church service, etc) will start with the native land acknowledgement proclamation by the host of the event. 

I don't recall the same thing happening in the US. 

Canadian gov also offered (my understanding Australian gov is also doing the same thing?):
1. Official apology
2. Creating reconciliation policy by creating and implementing the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, UNDRIP, etc. 

I don't recall the US gov providing an official apology for example which this book explained why imo: https://www.google.ca/books/edition/Myths_America_Lives_By/6cFwDwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=0

Is it enough what the Canadian gov does today? The damage has been done and only history can judge whether what the gov does today is enough because the repercussions of what happened in the past are still coming even to this day. In 2021 - 2022 for example, there was a finding of more than 1000 unmarked graves belonging to former children who attended the residential school. 

In any case, nice chatting with u but I gtg, I'm assuming u r not in Indonesia bcs it's 2AM WIB right now.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: The Kaimana is just a kingdom out of multiple kingdoms to be exist in Papua. Most coastal regions in Papua managed to be developed into kingdoms compared to the inner mainland and mountains still being tribal like people. Regions like Raja Ampat, Fakfak, and Kaimana managed to develop their own political entities that are at least more advanced than the inner mainlanders. During Tidore Sultanate period, many of them become vassals to Tidore, causing them to adopt Islam. When the Dutch take over these regions, even most of its populace still didn't know that they are under Dutch rule, so we can say that the Dutch presence is minimal and most likely contact the royal families and ministers to these kingdoms rather than addressing it to the public.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: At some point some Papuan rulers do fight against the Dutch expedition called the Hongi expedition, where they fought against the expedition sent by the Dutch to guard rempah rempah route by sea.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
1. Dasco: Deputy Speaker of the DPR, he was one of the four keys of Prabowo, mainly political operators in parliament. From his movement so far recently, one can state that he helps manage legislative strategy and maintain alliances. Moreover, he is responsible for possibly behind-the-scenes role in coalition negotiations and party consolidation. From a glance, he is the shadow negotiator, but actually playing a part in unifying the forces together, including the coalition of Gerindra.
2. Hasyim: Chairman of the KPU. Dud was basically playing a part in election regulation and management, especially during the 2024 election. He holds institutional power, though under questions for his neutrality. From his position alone, he can be a key player in shaping how electoral laws are interpreted and implemented.
3. Muzani: Obviously the Secretary General of Gerindra and DPR member at the same time. He is at least one of Prabowo‚Äôs most loyal lieutenants and inner-circle strategists based on his position and moves. From his position and decisions, he mainly helped Gerindra maintain internal cohesion and plays a possible kingmaker role in legislative politics.
4. Sjafrie: a retired general, and a former Deputy Minister of Defense from SBY era. Many already known him for his influence and possible shadow connections in the military, including defense-related policies. Though not mainly active, I can tell he played somewhat of an informal advisor  while being a part of the military elites. Sometimes he was being connected with Prabowo due to both of them having military background together.

Content: This is just the surface information about these four names along with speculations about them.

Author: anarchytex
Content: My brother wants to consider pursuing HI

Author: anarchytex
Content: What do you think of HI majors againts law majors etc

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Depends on which angles are we going to pursue here. Compared to HI, Stronger domestic demand will befall into positions such as lawyers, notaries, legal consultants, judges, and legal staff. In corporations and government, law majors are consistently needed. Meanwhile for HI, you would have competitive and niche job market though more exposed to other soft skills that can be developed such as language, writing, policy, negotiation, etc. If your brother is capable to expand those soft skills, then HI is a good way to go. IR is more flexible in terms of interdisciplinary and international career paths, with its relevance growing though the job positions are moving in still the same pace.

Author: anarchytex
Content: Ok where do IR majors usually apply to after they graduate, UN? Kemlu?

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Both UN and Kemlu are very tight spots. Many applied for that positions for each and every year with competitiveness. You can also taking jobs in media, journalism, corporate relations, academia, and even startup sectors.

Author: petrachristalbert
Content:
There is so many kinds of people that cant speak straight to the point (gak bisa berterus terang). So there will be someone that could easily communicate with people like that and get the point of what they want to say, we call em 'Reverse Yapping'.

Contohnya kayak ada orang yang padahal cuman mau ngejelasin kenapa dia telat, tapi ngomongnya putar putar sampai ada ketemu si A si B dan orang tuanya C. si 'Reverse Yapping' bakal dengan mudah dapat poin dari ceritanya bahwa penyebab keterlambatannya adalah telat bangun.

Mirip dengan sistem Teks Eksplanasi, kami manggil orang ini dengan 'Reverse Yapping'.

Author: woyaimon
Content: hellooo does anyone here study international relations and would like to explain to me a few puzzling stuff regarding the subject

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Hello, I am in IR, or at least about to graduate from it

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: What's up mate?

Author: woyaimon
Content: i have a hard time digesting the english school theory and im in the making of a group essay explaining the said theory

Author: woyaimon
Content: the question i got asked was about foreign policy as social acitivity, what does it actually implies?

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Hello sorry to reply just now, just done a few chores at midnight before coming back to this one. Suffice to say, in English School Theory, states are seen as members of international society. Nah, in their interactions on each other itself is an act of social activity, specifically diplomatic interactions as a socialization for states. Thus why foreign policy according to the theory, it becomes a way for states whether they want to interact, communicate, and reinforce or challenge norms within that society (their ongoing interactions will be known as Society of States).

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: How far have you been taught in this theory and what semester are you in? Since I believe this theory was supposed to be taught during early few semesters.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: But in any case, this is the reason why foreign policy is not merely strategic by English School Theory: it is also social, normative, and identity-driven. And the socialization between states through diplomatic interactions based on their foreign policy is what we called as social practice

Author: woyaimon
Content:
ah i see, so in other words, norms and different understanding of justice for each states is critical and plays a big role in terms of the construction of the fp correct?  
oh and also im currently reading linklater and suganami's book and they stress out the concept of good international citizenship, is that in some way a factor or a main principle in which the state holds its role as a member of intl society?

Author: woyaimon
Content:
i missed the lecture on the week they explained about this and they're only explaining one theory for one week so once its over its over lol
and yes im still currently on the 2nd sem

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Exactly, you are on the right track now yes. For Linklater and Suganami, they both highlight it as a moral and normative benchmark for states. It‚Äôs essentially a way to think about responsible behavior within the society of states. So when a state acts as a good international citizen, it reinforces the shared values and order of international society. It is a social expectation that is expected from them to do as a member of Society of States. Fulfilling it will grant them various benefits (recognition, legitimacy and influence).

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: It is what it is, I have to try studying on my own when the first few semesters are over, with my ongoing semesters had to made me review my works even further

Author: woyaimon
Content:
aaah okay now i get it
okay but heres another one. Bull in his writing contested about the goal of each state to preserve their sovereignty clashes with the goal of preserving the balance of power and maintaining peace. does that have anything to do with foreign policy as social activity? how?

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: That is a good connection. Bull in his writing emphasized the tension between sovereignty and order, which directly relates to foreign policy as a social activity because foreign policy is where states actively negotiate that tension. So, when Bull says there's a clash, foreign policy is where that clash is navigated. It becomes a social process of balancing.

Author: woyaimon
Content: okay, so to conclude, if my understanding is correct, state as a member of international society uses its foreign policy as a channel to drive its interactions, which is based on each moral principles and norms. but then, if any collision happens, that's when the state is faced with its choice to either prioritize national sovereignty or follow international order. aand that's on the natural process of balancing an international society.

Author: buzzer9229
Content: @everyone I've been reading people wanting to take up International Relations recently. Though I am happy people are taking in the same field as me, I must put a disclaimer as a former International Relations student: A degree in IR is practically useless if you're starting up from nothing because IR is a broad field that is more affiliated with academic circles, so as an IR student you're pushed to be a social scientist rather than a politician or diplomat. People that wanna take IR and do consulting or become a diplomat I suggest you guys take a different, more specialized field like Law or Governance or Sociology. Otherwise, your network game needs to be better and you need to be specialized in a certain field, especially if you graduate from universities that are not UI or UGM.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Itu kondisi ketika sebuah negara atau wilayah mengalami peningkatan proporsi penduduk usia produktif (sekitar 15‚Äì64 tahun) yang lebih besar (jadi jumlah populasi bertambah besar dan lebih besar) dibandingkan dengan penduduk usia non-produktif (di bawah 15 tahun dan di atas 64 tahun).

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
Ada, dampak positifnya paling umum itu:
1. Jumlah populasi siap bekerja itu semakin banyak
2. Jumlah potensi untuk daya saing global bisa meningkat
 
Dampak negatif:
1. Angka pengangguran bisa meningkat kalau tidak ada edukasi dan lapangan pekerjaan yang memadai.
2.  Kemiskinan struktural bisa meningkat tanpa ada program pemerintah yang cukup, sehingga bisa membuat jebakan kemiskinan

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: Mainly teach ofc, but in other cases: I also talk and socialize with them if we have free times, then showing them memes, etc. Then I also asked them about their life stories while advising them if I can since they asked some random questions a few times.

Author: darkzet
Content: whoops, what i meant is how do you mainly teach them? do you have your own methods? sorry for not being specific lol

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
There are multiple options I can do:
1. Asking them while engaging. A simple Socratic method can test their critical thinking skills to figure out some answers in certain subjects.
2. Using examples or analogy can also work in providing them relatable examples that they can understand
3. Sometimes I pop a joke or do storytelling inside the subjects to get their attentions when they got distracted for a bit.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: These are 3 basic methods I usually use

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: But for special need students, I have to double the efforts by guiding them more intensely and engaging

Author: gssstev
Content: Actually he did nothing bro hahaha‚Ä¶ What he did just let the market run by itself. De-industrilization happened when Mega signed the free trade agreement with China. All the low quality imports flooded the market, causing hundreds of people losing their job. Because small manufacturer turned into importer. More profit margins, with less headache working with tukang.

Author: gssstev
Content: During SBY term, SNI was created to manage this chaos. But eventually, the damage had been done. Traders, after tasting the huge margins and better quality of life, still decided to import goods, and paid the necessary paper work for SNI.

Author: gssstev
Content: And again we see the same pattern got repeated when PDIP win the election at 2014. More imports of Chinese goods for the past 10 years. Even the Chinese notice this, they tried to sell directly to end consumers, by passing distribution chain. Luckily, Aliexpress was banned, Shopee was warned not to allow direct selling from China.

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
Ok so I am finally done teaching for now while waiting for any students to come in, so I have some time to explain it even further. Back when I was voluntarily recruited to advise a kader doing his caleg run. He once had asked me about how to beat Gibran one on one since both of them are "younger" candidates. And I said: "you don't fight a prince on his throne, you fight him on the streets when his crown wasn't there. You don't stab him, but you let the people make a mockery of him, let the masses judge him if he lives by the masses support. You on the other hand, has to be one that could move that masses, which you don't have right now as he holds them by their golds."

There are a few things I've advised that are similar to what Buzzer stated here, so I will elaborate it:

1. Differentiate a clear vision and values
In order to beat Gibran, one must have the opposite yet strong image than him. Obvious choices for images would be meritocracy and clean governance, yet the thing is: not many can achieve it. A few that did, usually didn't have enough exposure to create that strong image. In terms of vision and values, Gibran is still lacking in communicating his plans for national security, education, economic transformation, and foreign policy. If you are his rival, you must enhance yourself in those sectors since those are what he mainly lacks. Expose him in that sector, then prove yourself that you are a more capable person for the job as a whole.
2. Smart Use of Media and Social Media
The usage of social media and AI promotions are where Gibran's promotional campaign shine during 2024. There is no doubt that Gibran will use it again if that was what can make him win two times in a row, both Mayorship and Vice Presidency. Gibran benefits from Jokowi‚Äôs media footprint and his advertisement. You as a rival need savvy digital campaigns with humor, clarity, and emotional resonance, including memes too (to both get youth support and needed exposure for your campaign).

Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content:
3. Public Debates & Dialogues
One thing that I heavily noticed, is the fact Gibran tends to be reserved and sometimes avoid debates. Mainly because we can saw that he is not good for a debater or a proper charismatic figure, at least not yet, so there is a good reason why we don't see him being recorded to speak in intellectual dialogues. But just like Buzzer stated, in those debates and dialogues, try to not approach him aggressively by attacking his statements. Try to focus on your policies, solutions and explaining it even further so you could be seen as a comprehensive figure that actually answered the questions in details. I knew that many Javanese tend to avoid debates, conflicts, and disagreements, but are willing to do discussions for the sake of harmony. It is crucial to make yourself can tackle his weak points and statements yet in a manner that is not "attacking" but "helping" and being genuine about your solutions for greater good.
4. Grassroots & Coalition Building
For the coalition part, I believe Buzzer had explained it very well. But for grassroots, I will note this is where Gibran can hold it as his strong points. After all, the bansos system was used to win the campaign in rural areas. Thus your strong points in winning the rural areas should not be coming welfare alone (giving bansos). Instead of just giving aid, build community empowerment programs (you should do this since day one before you even get into presidential race tho) like cooperative farming, digital literacy, or micro-business incubation. If resources allow, create symbolic yet practical rival programs. Contohnya ‚ÄúWarung Rakyat Mandiri,‚Äù a people-run food cooperative, or a volunteer-based community clinic that shows what people-led welfare looks like. Of course this is very ambitious and resource consuming programs, thus you will need a huge financial backing since day one.
